channel.title: Pk client [473]
channel.description:
a few days ago, i saw a topic about those old pking clients, and i got a bit inspired so i made this.
i never saw the old pking clients cause i came after that, so i dont know what to base it on also, i know they had differant coloured player dots, i tried that but it never completely covered it, always left some part showing, or covered too much, so i made it just show the combat level above the dot, but thats sometimes annoying when its crowded cause they all bunch up.
this was purposly made to be detectable, but if you put it in a loader, then i guess it would be pretty safe to use on a good account... also it needs to be updated when the client changes now when its outdated, i dont want anyone posting asking for an update, [i]you update it yourself, that how your learn[/i], and if you do update it, keep it to yourself
heres me running around that castle place [IMG]http://img81.imageshack.us/img81/1361/screenshotdf5.png[/img]

Yea, for example, don’t ever use static things as a pattern!
(Like your search for “Your account has been disabled.)”
[/quote]
I use static things as patterns, and they are yet to break
You just need to be intelligent when you are creating the transform, that’s all.[/quote]
Oh ok, thanks.
So my static ‘thing’ is ok?

item.title: Pk client [473]
item.dc:creator: @Polyfinite Polyfinite
item.description:
@Polyfinite wrote:

I know it was about a for loop, but I meant how would you find it?
I have since forgotten how you would do loops in bytecode instructions.
Oh, and I find entity through search for a constant utf8 entry having the value “Your account has been disabled.)3”.

edit:
Wait, so you’d use GOTO in bytecode?

EDIT2:
Oh, and va is packet it seems.
Has a UTF8 “modPow”, and has a UTF8 for java/math/BigInteger = RSA Encrypting, done in the packet class
Also, “toByteArray” is in the constant pool = PACKET CLASS
But “toString” is a bit unusual, I’ve never noticed it.

Read full topic

item.title: Pk client [473]
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

well Evan, if you dont know java, theres nothing you can do, but if you did know, you could make this run as an applet, instead of starting it as an application through main(), like make an applet loader

well Polyfinite, theres a few ways to find Entity, it has a lot of patterns in it you can use. you should get an old aryan deob which has been renamed a lot, and have a look at it there, then try to find the same thing in the current deob

for the outOfPlayerLoop thing, its just talking about a for loop, which goes through every player and draws it dot on the minimap, its this part from my slightly renamed deob, in the method drawMinimap()
the methods added with bcel have “//LOOK HERE” after them

	    for (int f = 0; Player.playerCount > f; f++) {
		Player player = (Class45.playerArray[Class33.playerIndicies[f]]);
		PKClient.drawMinimapPlayer(player); //LOOK HERE
		if (player != null && player.method877(true)) {
		    int i_17_ = (-((Class74_Sub12_Sub11.myPlayer.x) / 32) + player.x / 32);
		    int i_18_ = (-((Class74_Sub12_Sub11.myPlayer.y) / 32) + player.y / 32);
		    long l = player.name.method116((byte) -128);
		    boolean bool = false;
		    for (int i_19_ = 0; Class38.anInt761 > i_19_; i_19_++) {
			if (((l ^ 0xffffffffffffffffL) == (Class6.aLongArray1738[i_19_] ^ 0xffffffffffffffffL)) && Class74_Sub7_Sub14.anIntArray2604[i_19_] != 0) {
			    bool = true;
			    break;
			}
		    }
		    boolean bool_20_ = false;
		    if (((Class74_Sub12_Sub11.myPlayer.anInt3968) ^ 0xffffffff) != -1 && player.anInt3968 != 0 && ((Class74_Sub12_Sub11.myPlayer.anInt3968)== player.anInt3968))
			bool_20_ = true;
		    if (!bool) {
			if (!bool_20_)
			    Class50.markMinimap(i_17_, (byte) -25, i_18_,Class50.aClass74_Sub12_Sub18_Sub2Array963[2],i_0_, i);
			else
			    Class50.markMinimap(i_17_, (byte) -25, i_18_,Class50.aClass74_Sub12_Sub18_Sub2Array963[4],i_0_, i);
		    } else
			Class50.markMinimap(i_17_, (byte) -25, i_18_,(Class50.aClass74_Sub12_Sub18_Sub2Array963[3]),i_0_, i);
		}
	    }
PKClient.outOfPlayerLoop(); //LOOK HERE

PKClient.outOfPlayerLoop(); is just my way of telling myself that the client is out of the loop.

Read full topic

item.description:
@yakman wrote:

[quote=“Evan`, post:4, topic:152706”]'jar' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file. Compiling 'javac' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file. Could you tell me what’s wrong?[/quote]

install the jdk
but its already set up, press run-PKClient.bat and it should work, but since you pressed the Setup-RS.bat, its probably messed up, so download it again
